abstract.p: Letter by Robert Stein responds to May 25 article on cyberspace news; says article brings to mind the psychological significance of newspaper reading

block.p: The essay about reading news online calls to mind a phenomenon of longstanding interest to social scientists and critics, the psychological significance of newspaper reading. At issue is the comfort of a context for the disturbing news we experience immediately and viscerally on television. The mediation of a familiar front page and calm editorial commentary reassures us that the world has not been jarred loose from its moorings. Or as Marshall McLuhan put it: ''People don't actually read newspapers. They get into them every morning like a hot bath.''
